title: Drake Maye doesn’t think he has ‘too much on his plate’ and more from WEEI interview
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Drake Maye rejects the notion of scaling back his workload, citing the inherent responsibility of NFL quarterbacks.
Maye's third-quarter interception against the Raiders led to a momentum swing and 13 unanswered points for the opposition.
Bill Belichick banned Patriots scouts from UNC, a decision Maye discussed, acknowledging Belichick's authority over team practices.

title: ‘Game 1 is always the hardest’: Patriots veteran shares perspective on Will Campbell’s debut
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Rookie left tackle Will Campbell faced challenges in his NFL debut, including penalties and allowing two sacks.
Veteran tackle Morgan Moses noted Game 1 difficulties are common but can be learning opportunities for Campbell.
The Patriots' offensive struggles persisted, scoring only 13 points, below last season's average of 17 points per game.

title: Kayshon Boutte reflects on his forgotten history as an elite prospect
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Kayshon Boutte was a sixth-round pick in 2023 despite being a highly regarded prospect earlier in his career.
Boutte had a breakout performance in the Patriots' season opener, with six catches for 103 yards and five first-downs.
An ankle injury during his sophomore year at LSU affected Boutte's draft stock, but he has since become a key player for New England.

title: Hasbro is relocating its headquarters to Boston’s Seaport
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Hasbro is moving its headquarters from Pawtucket, Rhode Island, to Boston's Seaport by the end of 2026.
The new 265,000-square-foot headquarters at 400 Summer St. will house roughly 700 full-time employees.
Governor Maura Healey and Mayor Michelle Wu expressed support for Hasbro's move to Massachusetts.

title: Wu heads into preliminary election with massive 50-point lead over Kraft
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu leads Josh Kraft by 50 points in a recent Emerson College poll for the Boston mayoral race.
The poll shows 72% of likely voters support Wu, while 22% back Kraft, ahead of the preliminary election.
Wu's popularity has grown amid criticism from the Trump administration; voters largely oppose potential National Guard deployment.

title: Dunkin’ franchisee closes down production plant, lays off 74 employees
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: NGP Management is closing its Haverhill production plant, resulting in 74 employee layoffs starting November 3.
The layoffs at 15 Parkridge Road facility include production workers, drivers, logistic supervisors, and a baker.
A new 100,000 sq ft Dunkin' facility is being built at 30 Creek Brook Drive, expected to open by year's end.

title: Bill Belichick statue at Gillette? Here’s what more than 1,000 readers said.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Over 1,000 Boston.com readers weighed in on a potential Bill Belichick statue at Gillette Stadium.
46% of readers supported a Belichick statue, while 52% opposed, citing his rocky end with the team.
Fans praised Belichick's role in six Super Bowl wins, while critics questioned his rapport with fans and recent performance.

title: Pair from Brighton facing charges in string of handicap placard thefts
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Andrea Doucette-Keating, 55, and Zachary Shelton, 37, face charges for handicap placard thefts in Allston-Brighton.
Doucette-Keating allegedly stole placards, while Shelton organized the operation and distributed stolen items.
Searches at Shelton's residence uncovered multiple stolen placards and drugs; both suspects face multiple felony charges.

title: Why did the Patriots abandon the run against the Raiders? Mike Vrabel explains.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots shifted focus to passing, with 46 attempts by Drake Maye, abandoning run game against the Raiders.
TreVeyon Henderson, Rhamondre Stevenson, and Antonio Gibson combined for only 18 carries and 60 yards.
Vrabel emphasized offensive line struggles and need for a more effective and efficient run game.

title: The T’s ‘fare engagement representatives’ are hitting the streets today. Here’s what to expect.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: MBTA launches fare checks with 'fare engagement representatives' issuing warnings or citations to fare evaders in Boston.
First fare evasion offense receives a written warning; fines range from $50 to $150 for multiple offenses.
Massachusetts decriminalized fare evasion in 2021, but financial losses lead MBTA to implement new measures.
